citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
On July 28, 2023, at an IACUC meeting, the committee was informed of two pigs that were euthanized due to post-
surgical complications after an acute kidney injury and contralateral nephrectomy surgery. During the IACUC's
investigation it was determined the combination of these procedures was not approved by the IACUC. Protocols carried
out by the PI without IACUC approval could result in animal welfare and health concerns. The IACUC must be able to,
review and approve, required modifications in (to secure approval), or withhold approval of proposed significant changes
regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities.
Corrected by the time of inspection.

On August 21, 2023, an IACUC committee met to review records and interview personnel. In reviewing the records, the
committee determined that the PI acknowledged their team had large animal care limitations and were unclear on who
was supposed to provide care for the animals post-operatively. Per the Attending Veterinarian, they were called upon to
provide care and ultimately euthanized the pigs due to complications post-operatively. Training for all personnel dealing
with animals is imperative to provide proper care. It shall be the responsibility of the research facility to ensure that all
scientists, research technicians, animal technicians, and other personnel involved in animal care, treatment, and use are
qualified to perform their duties. This responsibility shall be fulfilled in part through the provision of training and instruction
to those personnel.
To be corrected by October 24, 2024.

During the review of protocols APHIS Officials found during a guinea pig protocol (IS 9030) of Small Animal Imagining Lab
a guinea pig expired 10 minutes after placing it in the anesthesia chamber. This event was reported to the IACUC during
its January 26, 2024 meeting. According to the meeting minutes the Moffitt veterinarian believed this was most likely a
positioning issue and recommended getting a larger chamber to accommodate larger animals. Proper handling of the
animals undergoing these protocols is essential for the welfare of the animals under the facility's care. Handling of all
animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating,
excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
To be corrected by October 25, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Attending Veterinarian.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
